§1 Metric Space
Denition 1.1 (Metric). A function
d: X
2
→ R
∀x, y, z ∈ X satisfying:
a) d(x, y) = 0 ↔ x = y;
b) d(x, y) = d(y, x) (symmetry);
c) d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z) (triangle inequality),
is called a metric or distance in X. Such X is said to be equiped with a metric d, (X, d) is called
a metric space. If the metric dened over X is denite, we just simply call the X the metric
space.

Lemma 1 (Quadruple inequality). Let (X, d) be a metric space.
∀a, b, u, v ∈ X,


d(a, b) − d(u, v)


≤ d(a, u) + d(b, v) (1-4)
Proof. Without loss of generality, we assume that d(a, b) > d(u, v). According to the triangle
inequality (see def. 1.1), d(a, b) ≤ d(a, u) + d(u, v) + d(v, b), which is to prove.
Denition 1.2 (δ-ball). Let (X, d) be a metric space, and δ ∈ R
+
, a ∈ X. A set
B(a; δ) = {x ∈ X | d(a, x) < δ}
is then called a ball with a centre at a ∈ X and a radius of δ, or a ball of point a.
Denition 1.3. The diametre of a set A ⊂ X, is dened as:
d(A) := sup{d(x, y) | x, y ∈ A}.
The distance between a set and a point, and the distance between sets are dened as:
d(A, a) := inf{d(x, a) | x ∈ A}, d(A, B) := inf{d(x, y) | x ∈ A, y ∈ B}.

A closed ball

Denition 1.6 (Neighbourhood). If x ∈ X is an element of an open set, then such open set is
called a neighbourhood of point x in X, denoted by U(x). The collection of all neighbourhoods
of x can be denoted by U (x).

Denition 1.7 (Interior point). Let x ∈ X, E ⊂ X.
a) If ∃U(x) ⊂ E, x is called an interior point of E.
b) If ∃U(x) ⊂ X − E, x is called an exterior point of E.
c) If x isn’t an interior point nor exterior point of E, it is called a boundary point of E. The
set of boundary points is called boundary, denoted by ∂E.
Denition 1.8 (Limit point). a ∈ X, E ⊂ X. If ∀U(a), card

E ∩ U(a)

= ∞, a is called a limit
point of E.
Denition 1.9 (Closure). The intersections of E ⊂ X and set of all its limit points is called the
closure of E, denoted by E.
Theorem 1.1. Let F ∈ 2
X
. F is a closed set in X ↔ F = F .
Proof. →: ∁
X
(F ) is open, hence its elements are all its interior points. Therefore F − F =
F ∪ ∁
X
(F ) = ∅, also we know that F ⊂ F , hence F = F .
←: F = F means that ∀x ∈ ∁
X
(F ), x is not a boundary of F , which implies that x is an interior
point of X − F . Therefore X − F is open while F is closed.
Theorem 1.2. E is always closed.
Proof. ∀x ∈ X − E, since it is not an element of the set E nor its limit points, ∃U(x) s.t.
U(x) ∩ E = ∅, which implies that x is an extorior point of E, therefore E is closed.
Theorem 1.3. E = E.
Proof. Since E is closed, its complement is open, which implies that its elements are all exterior
points of E, therefore E has contained all of its limit points.

Denition 2.4 (Weight). The smallest possible cardinity of a base of a topology is called the

Denition 2.5 (Neighbourhood). If x ∈ U (x) and U(x) ∈ T , then U (x) is a neighbourhood of

Denition 2.7 (Dense set). E ⊂ X is a dense set in the topological space (X, T ), if ∀x ∈ X,
∀U(x), U (x) ∩ E 6= ∅.
Denition 2.8 (Separable). If there is a countable dense set in topological space (X, T ), then
(X, T ) is separable.
We can also dene interior points, exterior points, boundary points, limit points in topological
space as in metric space.

§4 Connected Set
Denition 4.1 (Connected space). Topological space (X, T ) is called connected if there is no
open-closed set (i.e. both open and closed) besides ∅ and X itself.
Notice that if A ∈ 2
X
is open-closed, its complement X − A is also open-closed, which means a
topological space is connected i it is not a union of its two open subsets.

Denition 4.3 (Locally connected). A topological space (X, T ) is said to be locally connected
if ∀x ∈ X, ∃U (x) s.t. U (x) is connected.

§8 Normed Linear Space
Denition 8.1 (Norm). Let V be a linear space over R or C. A function k k: X → R assigning to
each vector x ∈ X a real number kxk is called a norm in the linear space X if:
a) kxk = 0 ↔ x = 0 (nondegeneracy);
b) kλxk = |λ|kxk (homogeneity);
c) kx
1
+ x
2

1

A linear space with a norm dened on it is said to be normed.
Over every normed space a distance can be dened as:

Denition 8.2 (Banach space). Let V be a normed space. If (V, d) is a complete space, where the
distance d is dened as Eq. (8-1), then we call V a complete normed space or Banach space.

§11 Finite-Increment Theorem

Theorem 11.7 (Constant if derivative is zero in a connected open set). Let X, Y be normed spaces,
U be a connected open set in X, f ∈ Y
U

(x) = O, then
f is a constant function from U .
Proof. Let x
0

0

First, E is open. ∀x ∈ E, ∃B(x; δ) ⊂ U. Since ∀x
0
∈ B(x; δ), [x, x

Then, U − E is also open in the topological subspace U, with the same reason.
Since E is not empty, (x
0
∈ E), the only choice for a open-closed set in a connected set U is U
itself, i.e. ∀x ∈ U, f (x) = f (x

Theorem 16.4 (Darboux’s criterion). Let f ∈ R
I
, where I is a cuboid in a n-D space. f ∈ R(I)

§17 Riemann Integral over Jordan Measurable Sets
Denition 17.1 (Jordan Measurable). A set E in an n-D normed space X is said to be Jordan
measurable if it is bounded, and its boundary ∂E is of measure zero.
In fact, Jordan measurable set is not a σ-algeba. For example, sets of a single points in R
n
is
Jordan measurable, but their countable union Q
n
∩ [0, 1]
n
is not Jordan measurable.
Lemma 9 (Jordan measurable sets is closed under nite union, nite intersection and dierence).
If A, B are two Jordan measurable sets, A ∩ B, A ∪ B, A − B are also Jordan measurable.
Proof. Only to notice that ∂(A ∪ B) ⊂ ∂A ∪ ∂B, ∂(A ∩ B) ⊂ ∂A ∪ ∂B, ∂(A − B) ⊂ ∂A ∪ ∂B.

A 1-D surface is always called a curve.

§23 Orientation of a Surface
Algebra has taught us that we can nd a basis h
ˆ
e
i
i
i∈n
for R
n
and the transformation from one
basis to another is taken by a non-degenerate matrix P .
Denition 23.1 (Orientation classes of frames). Two bases are said to belong one orientation
class of frames if the transform matrix between them has a positive determinent.
It is clear that there are two orientation classes of frames.
Now consider two open and connected set G and D in R
n
, whose dieomorphism is witnessed
by φ : D → G. If for each point t ∈ D, we translate the basis of R
n
at t as the basis of the tangent
space TD
t
.
As we have shown in our previous chapter, φ
0
(t) is the isomorphism from TD

to TG
x
(x :=
φ(t)), and therefore maps a basis of TD
t
to a basis of TG
x
.
Since det φ
0
6= 0 (or there would be no inverse), det φ
0
∈ C(D; R) and D is connected, we know
that either ∀t ∈ D, det φ
0
(t) > 0 or ∀t ∈ D, det φ
0
(t) < 0. Therefore we are able to nd two
orientation classes of G, by the choice of dieomorphism φ, or, in other words, the curvilinear
coordinates of G.
We apply these discussions to the denition of the orientation of a surface:
Denition 23.2 (Consistence of two charts). Let S be a k-D surface, (φ
i
, U
i
), i ∈ 2 be two charts
of S. If ∀x ∈ U
0
∩ U

0

(t

) > 0 (i.e. with a same sign) where t

−1

(x), i ∈ 2,
then we say that these two charts are consistent.
Denition 23.3 (Orienting atlas and orientable surface). If an atlas is made up of charts consistent
pairwisely, we say that it is an orienting atlas.
If a surface has an orienting atlas, we say that it is an orientable surface. Otherwise we say
that it is an nonorientable surface.
Denition 23.4 (Orientation class of atlases). We can dene such a equivalence relation that,
if the union of two orienting atlases is also a orienting atlas, we say they are equivalent. Such
equivalence relation induces an equivalence class, called orientation class of atlases.
A surface with a certain class of atlases is said to be oriented, or we say that we have a
orientation of the surface.
A geometry theorem told us that a orientable connected surface has two dierent orientations,
the proof would be given later.

§24 The Boundary of a Surface and Its Orientation
The denition of k-D surface has some defects: what if we want to discuss the half space H

Denition 24.1 (Surface with boundary). Let S ⊂ R
n
. If ∀x ∈ S, ∃U ∈ U (x) s.t. U is dieo-

If φ: H

of S. The collection of all boundary point of S is said the boundary of the surface S, denoted
by ∂S.
The boundary of a surface is not the topological boundary of the set.
Since the parametre domain might varies for surface with boundary, we usually denote a chart
of S by (T, φ, U), where U = R
